did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: The World War II Collection contains information relating to the participation in and experiences of Georgetown residents during World War II.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the G&B Cultural Center.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item Description, Date], World War II Collection, [Item no., Box no.], G&B Cultural Center, Wilton, Conn.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: The United States entered World War II following the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on December 7, 1941. The conflict with Japan ended August 15, 1945. Germany surrendered on May 7, 1945.

In Georgetown, Conn., as elsewhere in the United States, the local community experienced the war through the draft and volunteering for service of young men and women; rationing of gasoline and other essentials; participation in the war effort through the Red Cross, growing "victory" gardens, and other activities.
According to the research of Marianne Fisher, these are the names of the 215 men and women from Georgetown who served in World War II:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The World War II Collection includes newspapers, newspaper clippings, and periodicals published domestically for the public and abroad for the troops. Books and pamphlets for general audiences and for servicemen, including War Department publications, are also in the collection. There is a large number of photographs, including many press proofs and prints from the U.S. Army Pictorial Service. Finally, the collection contains a number of maps, miscellaneous ephemera and realia, a few posters and banners, and signage from a 2010 exhibit held at the Gilbert & Bennett School.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Collections
relatedmaterial.p: The Wilton Historical Society holds World War II collections relating to the military service of Georgetown resident William Arthur Smith.
